Crime and Punishment

Raskolnikov was all over the place, not really sure what he was doing. "I might bring you something else soon, Alyona Ivanovna—a valuable thing—silver—a cigarette box, once I get it back from a friend..." He trailed off, feeling awkward.

"Alright, we can chat about it later," she replied.

"Bye—are you always home alone? Your sister isn't here?" He asked casually as he moved toward the door.

"What’s it to you, good sir?" she shot back.

"Just curious. Chill out… Good day, Alyona Ivanovna." 

As Raskolnikov stepped outside, confusion hit him hard. He paused on the stairs, struck by a thought. Once on the street, he shouted, "Oh, God, this is all so disgusting! Can I really… No, that’s just crazy!" He shook his head. "How could I even think such a terrible thing? My heart is capable of such filth. It’s all just gross, really gross!—and for a whole month I’ve been...," but he couldn’t find the words to express how he felt. 

The intense disgust that had started to weigh him down before meeting the old woman was now overwhelming. He felt lost, walking like a drunk, bumping into people without even noticing.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences intense confusion and repulsion after a troubling encounter with Alyona Ivanovna, reflecting on the dark thoughts that have plagued him.
